I don #8217;t think there #8217;s ever been a period of more blurred lines between #8220;serious cinema #8221; / big IPOs like GoT / Star Wars / MCU and peak TV than in the last few years, and I don #8217;t think this helped with the nature of analysing on the end of GoT
WRITING.TEXT: #8203; \*\*Warning #8211; ranty think out loud thread about cognitive dissonance around this. Not sure how internally consistent my arguments are\*\* One of the things I think is quite an interesting thought process is that if you think of GoT as on the verge of cinema as opposed to TV, a lot of season 8 and the reaction made sense, though it may take years to understand. GoT became this incredibly hard thing to categorise. It was so often spoken about in the terms of the Avengers/MCU and Star Wars franchises, yet we all know those are very different things from GoT. It #8217;s hard not to, especially given the fact D and D had been touted for Star Wars for much of the year. It #8217;s hard not to when two of your cast are off to join the MCU. But Star Wars and the MCU, as a general rule don #8217;t launch in to serious Oscar campaigns for above the line acting/directing awards, though they might for special FX. GoT had an incredible amount of crossover to franchise and other work, and franchise work has had such a crossover to the Serious Acting Oscar Films. Johanssen and Pugh are Emmy nominees one day and in an MCU promo the next, the Thrones cast are doing long promo tours with a host of very present day Oscar winners and nominees (aka Sophie Turner positioned alongside Jessica Chastain and Jennifer Lawrence before she had a time to breathe post-GoT). There #8217;s more views on the GoT trailer than the Parasite Trailer, there #8217;s exponentially more views on the video of the Thrones cast presenting an Emmy together than Dern and Zellweger #8217;s Oscar acceptance speeches combined #8211; and Dern and Zellwegger aren #8217;t getting standing ovations on top of standing ovations. People spent disproportionate amounts of time analysing Kit Harington #8217;s Jon Snow performance in a way no one was analysing four time Emmy winner Jim Parsons #8217; performance on The Big Bang Theory nor even Adam Drivers #8217; three Emmy noms on Girls a few years before. But Driver went from Girls to Star Wars to Oscar Nominee, one of many examples of crossover. Harington is joining the MCU. Why WOULDN #8217;T our brains go there? How do you not look at Daenerys Targaryen or Jon Snow as superheroes for a happy ending when you can go buy figurines of them (something both adults and children are inclined to do) as the same place as Superman or Thanos? Do we know where the Thrones cast are going to end up? Is, for instance, Dern #8217;s performance in Marriage Story so disproportionately better than the GoT cast at their best? (I love Laura, but I #8217;d argue not particularly). Do we know if D and D are going to be funtime Netflix TV show creators or whether they #8217;ll helm the next Netflix Oscar push? No wonder HBO has no idea whether to make Daenerys and Her Dragons Superhero trailer or play on the complexity of Dany #8217;s journey, or whether to do cute HBO Max ads with Dany standing with Aquaman (played by Daenerys #8217; ex on screen husband) and Wonderwoman . How do you not take Emilia very, very seriously when she #8217;s the female headline of a film the year before over Awards Darling Phoebe Waller Bridge bumbling along as a droid? How do you logistically decide to or whether not to campaign for Gwendoline Christie when people spent more time bemoaning the underuse of her acting talent in Star Wars than they did for Oscar winner Lupita Nyongo in the same film at the same time as she #8217;s fifteenth credited on GoT? Or position a play for Alfie Allen when you hear he #8217;s in an excellent film that #8217;s a Best Oscar contender this year by a director who a hot minute ago was directing #8230;. a Thor movie? How do you discern the D and D hate-train when we see #8220;I can #8217;t believe he did that #8221; TLJ director Rian Johnson pop up two years later with a Best Oscar Screenplay nomination in a film with quite an opposite reaction? And, going back to #8220;how seriously do we take franchise stuff #8221;, how do we not in a 24 month period when Black Panther does get nominated and Joaquin Phoenix wins an Oscar for playing the Joker? I don #8217;t know what the answer to this is, and it #8217;s probably not a question that can be answered for today, or maybe not for years. But it #8217;s a messy mental roadmap at this point in time to discern just what GoT is, or isn #8217;t in public consciousness. Will some of the cast springboard to Oscar darlings? Will D and D write Netflix's next Oscar contender? Who knows?

WRITING.TITLE: An interesting scene. Interested in peoples' thoughts on Tyrion's view of Daenerys throughout the series?
Do people realise there's basically no evidence to suggest interest in GoT has reduced significantly?
WRITING.TEXT: I could bore you all with a long list of television ratings, Google trends, and various IMDB visitor data suggesting that people still are completely fascinated by Game of Thrones. There's only one show that even comes close with interest a year later, and that's Breaking Bad. The narrative I see on the internet that "no one cares about GoT anymore" just doesn't add up when you actually start researching if that's true. People might not talk about it as much because they feel it's hard to do so without arguments, but there's an abundance of interest in various aspects of the show. \*\*Edit: An exception to the rule is that the engagement on social media is somewhat down for various members of the cast, but a good portion of them don't post much GoT stuff and that's a fairly fickle metric. However, for all hate-train of a small minority on Twitter, the follow rate for the official Game of Thrones account is 8.4 million vs this time last year at 8.5 million percent\*\*

WRITING.TITLE: Stuff I Hope The TV Industry Learns from Game of Thrones
WRITING.TEXT: 1. Treat casting like your life depended on it. Choose people who'll stay with you until they need to leave via the story, not so you need to adapt the story to suit them leaving. 2. Shoot more outside of the US. There are some beautiful locations all around the world (also: it may not be the best time to shoot in the US at the moment) plus great facilities and it helps local economies (ie Northern Ireland) 3. Define character looks! We'll all remember Jon and Dany's hair, the Lannister red and gold, Cersei's perpetual wine glass. It helps characters be memorable and iconic. Even if you don't have the budget for big FX, great costumes and visuals are still appreciated. 4. It is delightful to have more than just one female characters whose story is being told in a story. Do that more. 5. Don't ever assume the final book of that cool series you're adapting is ACTUALLY gonna come out.

WRITING.TITLE: Which other characters, given different circumstances, also had high propensity to succumb to their worst instincts, but didn't?
WRITING.TEXT: If we accept that characters like Jaime and Dany succumbing to the worst of their instincts is what got them killed (you don't have to agree with that, but if you accept that argument), who also was at the highest of risk? One of my feelings was perpetually Arya. I think Arya's cool to watch and a fun character, but I've always been a little uneasy with her being painted as a hero at a certain point given what that meant about vengeful killing and a certain coldness attached to it, particularly in seasons 6 and 7. To me, Arya may well have a level of this urge, but what she's learnt - increasingly - is to walk away from it and not towards it. Tyrion's desire for greatness and to be heroic, to always be on the politically winning team very nearly had him dead as well.

Hypothetically, you have to develop a lower budget single season spin off for HBO because House of The Dragon is delayed by the pandemic and there are $$$ constraints. Using one character/actor, one location, and little to no CGI, what would you create?
WRITING.TEXT: So to be clear this is a thought experiment post (there #8217;s no indication this is a thing #8211; yet) I just thought it would be an interesting exercise: Let #8217;s pretend that HBO becomes severely delayed on the prequel because of the pandemic #8211; ie it #8217;s still happening, but it needs some time and they #8217;re seriously budget constrained but they do have access to previous cast members they might not and they decide to do a sequel/spin off (in reality: let's hope it doesn't come to this) **RULES OF THIS EXERCISE** You #8217;re allowed: \-One existing character/actor to carry over, and only one, because budget. You CANNOT recast, so you have to chose whether you chose an interesting character to link to a different storyline, or develop a storyline/arc around that character/actor (you don't necessarily need to make this a one person show, though) \-One season/central storyline, because this is a show to tide over the fandom until a bigger budget prequel can logistically happen (for this exercise #8211; you get 6-8 episodes) in, say, five years. \-One location, because COVID problems (ie you can check in with Edmure, Gendry at his castle, Greyworm at Naath) #8230;but you cannot move from location to location. \-No resurrections are allowed. \-No significant CGI (aka you can dress people up as white walkers or use real dogs for direwolves, receive ravens and talk about dragons, but you cannot CGI in big battles or dragons) \-You can time jump if you wish (it doesn #8217;t need to be set 2 minutes after the finale) \-You can chose a writer/director if you wish.

List of post GOT cast projects and current status (updated/updating/feel free to add/clarify)
WRITING.TEXT: \*I know this is incomplete but it's like 1am here (Nathalie, Pedro, etc). Will come back to, or feel free to help. This is projects that were either completed/in post production, not new and upcoming stuff (we could probably do with a thread for that) that is in various states of distribution. Most of it is going to VOD. **Emilia Clarke** * Above Suspicion is completed (a long time ago) Listed as getting a UK VOD release later this month. Despite there being some reports of getting a cinema release by Roadside (which is a Lionsgate division) I couldn #8217;t find any evidence. * Last Christmas has gone to VOD and in most places streaming during COVID. **Kit Harington** * The Eternals #8211; Listed as in post. Moved to February 2021. You all likely know the deal with wide release Disney. Could move at any time * The Death and Life of John Donovan #8211; this seems to be completely over theatre wise now and should be in VOD in all regions by now I believe. **Peter Dinklage** * I Care A Lot #8211; this is a at least in Post Production but doesn #8217;t have distribution yet in any major markets. * The Croods 2 (animated) #8211; (Dreamworks) #8211; this is supposed to be out in December. Probably could go VOD. It #8217;s animated. **Lena Headey** * Did a TV pilot for Showtime (Rita) just before COVID hit, shot in LA. At this point there #8217;s no word on this but I would imagine we should know fairly soon. * Gunpowder Milkshake wrapped late last year and has distribution. Has a distribution deal with STX in the US. Is listed as coming out this year but no specific date. I believe STX are test-driving Greenland (with Gerard Butler) which as of next month with technically has a cinema date #8211; so #8211; later in the year I guess? This is an action film and will probably be held off for a cinema release. * Twist wrapped late last year and as far as I can tell will go to telemovie in the UK (Sky) and VOD in the US, presumably streaming or VOD elsewhere. **Maisie Williams** OK quite a lot: * TV: Filmed Two Weeks To Live last year. This is definitely getting a release on Sky in the UK. No distribution deal outside UK that I can see, but that's fairly common with Sky Originals I believe. Maisie said in a live interview that this will maybe be out around Oct/Nov but unconfirmed. Has done some light press so might be earlier. * The New Mutants: Obviously this has a wide distribution deal and probably needs to be available everywhere at the same time. Still on the schedule for August 14. Probably will win an award for most delayed film in history, but who knows? * Wrapped The Owners film last year. Has a distribution deal - This is with RLJE who don #8217;t have a big track record in the last few years of much $$$ at the box office. This was slated as concurrent VOD/theatres in April and I suspect will go VOD unless things change. Listed as September release. **Sophie Turner** #183; Survive is on Quibi. It's complete. You can also watch it on a big screen now through Airplay etc. She is also on one "bit #8221; of The Princess Bride but it really is about 30 seconds and available on YouTube. #183; Did a film Broken Solider #8211; completed early 2019 #8211; I don #8217;t think this is going to get any sort of release. Has no distribution deals anywhere or festivals scheduled. #183; Had another film Heavy shown at the Deauville American Film Festival in France a bit under a year ago. Doesn #8217;t have any distribution deals - these can take a while - but this wasn't a big festival in the first place. **Nikolaj Coster Waldau** #183; Did a TV pilot post VOD (Gone Hollywood). Has definitively not been picked up. #183; Has an indie film called The Silencing going to DirecTV in the US on July 16th (so this week). No distribution I can see outside of the US. This is in English. #183; Exit Plan (also known by multiple other names) came out on VOD/streaming in most regions over the course of the last two months. I have seen this #8211; it is a bit of a hybrid of Danish/English. #183; Has a film called A Taste of Hunger (in Danish) which I believe is getting Scandinavian telemovie release next year #183; The Day We Died (in Danish) #8211; this has a had a cinema and VOD release in Denmark and I don #8217;t think is getting anything wider. **Gwendoline Christie** This is kind of convoluted. Basically the only person who has much in theatres: #183; The Personal History of David Copperfield #8211; probably the closest to an awards contender - this is super convoluted but has been released in the UK and is now at VOD status, is at the top of the box office in Australia and I think is getting a slow release in different regions BUT is owned by Disney/Searchlight in the US and is supposed to be out next month (this is PG and could probably also go Disney+ or Hulu). #183; In Fabric #8211; small A24 in the US horror film that is in either first or re-release cinemas in some markets even now and VOD in others. #183; A Midsummer Night #8217;s Dream #8211; this is a filmed stage production that was in limited release pre COVID and is popular to the extent of petitions for a digital/DVD release. Got massive numbers on a week of streaming (National Theatre is doing some sort of experiment). Is already in re-release in some theatres. #183; The Friend #8211; this is complete as was in film festivals in 2019 #8211; this has a stack of distribution deals including one in the US with Roadside (Lionsgate offshoot) #8211; will probably? Get a mix of VOD and theatrical releases (apparently Fall 2020) **Alfie Allen** #183; TV: White House Farm. This also has Gemma Whelan in it and Mark Addy (both in quite big roles) and Alfie in supporting. This has already been on ITV in the UK and Foxtel in Australia and has a deal with HBO Max in the US but I haven #8217;t seen any press that it #8217;s dropped yet? (I binged this. I really liked it) #183; How To Build A Girl #8211; this was meant to get a Lionsgate release in the UK but is going to Prime, and it got a very tiny drive-in release in the US which is now complete and I think is going to streaming.
